results.title: Colloids
results.brief_description: A description of the properties of colloidal suspensions, concentrating on the means of preventing coagulation by attraction between particles. Examples are taken from everyday occurrence including the activity of detergents on oils.

results.title: Collins Street Walk
results.creator_credit: Tony Evans, Swinburne Institute of Technology. Film and Television School and Paul Connor
results.brief_description: Children from Fitzroy Primary School are shown on the National Trust’s Collins Street Walk. They then use the graphics facility at Swinburne Institute’s computer installation to create an animated film based on the experience. Suitable for upper primary level.

results.title: Colleges of Advanced Education
results.creator_credit: John Martin-Jones, Australian Commonwealth Film Unit and Malcolm Smith
results.brief_description: Colleges of Advanced Education offer a practical alternative to University training in a number of technical and creative fields. This film examines the wide range of studies being undertaken in Colleges of Advanced Education, all over Australia.

results.title: Collectors
results.creator_credit: Swinburne Institute of Technology. Film and Television School, Luigi Acquisto, Chris McGill and Diana Leach
results.brief_description: An inventive and funny documentary that looks at various types of collections: snow domes, frogs, spark plugs, etc. Even more interesting are the collectors themselves who are forever in search of that ‘gem’.

results.title: Collectors
results.brief_description: An inventive and funny documentary that looks at various types of collections. Reg collects spark plugs and Margot collects frogs. Even more interesting are the collectors. There is a thriving sub-culture of ‘object hunters’ out there, attending swap meets and fetes in search of that ‘ gem ‘. Some say it’s all in the chase while others prefer the find!

results.title: Collars and cuffs
results.brief_description: A slapstick silent comedy about the high jinx that occurs at the Rough and Wet Laundry between the laundry clerk and his boss as they struggle to complete their tasks on time. The story ends with disastrous results as the washing tub overflows with hot, soapy water - spilling on to the streets and wreaking havoc. Featuring Stan Laurel, Mark Jones, Eddie Baker, Katherine Grant.

results.title: Collaborator
results.brief_description:
Collaborator presents a unique opportunity for teachers and students of theatre to explore issues, processes and the personnel associated with the creation of a new piece of Australian Theatre. This CD ROM provides insight into the creation of Arena Theatre Compnay’s PANACEA through interviews, formal and informal, with the artists involved and footage of the production in both rehearsal and in performance.

Peter Robert, Head of Drama, Yarra Valley Grammar School

results.title: Cold water survival
results.creator_credit: Heather Cook and Canadian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description: University of Victoria scientists have found that those people who accidently die in water, do so as a result of exposure rather than drowning. Hypothermia occurs when the body temperature drops to 80 degrees fahrenheit. In their research, the scientists have also found out how the body loses heat and how this can be minimised, and have designed a life jacket, which by helping to conserve body heat, can prolong life.

results.title: Cold war. Vol. 6. Episodes 21-24: Final countdown
results.creator_credit: Martin Smith, Jeremy Isaacs Productions and Turner Original Productions
results.brief_description: The final volume of the six volume television series “Cold War” features episodes 21 to 24 and covers the period from 1944 to 1994. KGB spying began in Los Alamos where scientists worked in secrecy to develop America’s first atomic bomb and by the 1940s they had successfully infiltrated the heart of Western intelligence. The CIA counter attacked with their own espionage operations. Between the 1940s-1960s, there was intelligence and counterintelligence, spies and double spies, names such as Philby, Burgess and Maclean, but gradually human spies would be replaced by technology by means of photography and electronic eavesdropping. Satellites would be able to intercept radio communications and the Soviets began to fear they were losing ground to American technology. The 1980s represented a time of change in the Cold War and particularly in the disarmament of nuclear weapons, with Ronald Reagan as the US President and Mikhail Gorbachev as leader of the Soviet Union. Gorbachev introduced “perestroika” (restructuring) and “glasnost” (openness) and in 1985, the two leaders met in Geneva for the first superpower summit in six years. In 1986, the Chernobyl disaster rocked the Soviet Union and six months later, Gorbachev and Reagan agreed to the complete withdrawal of intermediate range missiles in Europe and a 50% reduction in ballistic missiles over a five year period. However, during all of this negotiating, Reagan persisted with his “Star Wars” theory, or Strategic Defense Initiative through to the end of his presidency in 1989. Gorbachev’s perestroika began filtering through the Soviet bloc, including Hungary and Poland, but the most dramatic moment came when in 1989 the Berlin Wall came down, opening up East and West Berlin. However this epic event also signalled the crumbling of the Kremlin and its control over Eastern Europe as well as leading to the demise of Gorbachev, the Soviet Communist Party and the end of the USSR and the rise of Boris Yeltsin and the newly created Commonwealth of Independent States. Bush, on Christmas Day, 1991, announced to the world that the Cold War confrontation between the two superpowers was now over. Narrated by Kenneth Branagh. (For more information see www.cnn.com/SPECIALS/cold.war)
